article.title: StarHorse: A Bayesian tool for determining stellar masses, ages, distances, and extinctions for field stars

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following is NOT a decision made based on user input in the StarHorse flux diagram?
choices: Whether to correct photometry for reddening

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 illustrate about the spatial distribution of Galactic components?
choices: The bulge dominates at close distances in directions towards the inner Galaxy.
The halo is the most dominant component at all distances in all directions.
The thick disk dominates at close distances in directions away from the Galactic center.
The contribution of all components is equal at a distance of 5 kpc in all directions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What general trend is observed in the relative errors of age estimations for simulated stars in Figure 3?
choices: Age errors decrease with increasing metallicity.
Age errors are more frequent and severe for stars younger than 1 Gyr.
Age errors are consistently larger for giant stars compared to dwarf stars.
Age errors are independent of other stellar parameters.

multiple_choice_question.text: Compared to the PARSEC simulations, the TRILEGAL simulations exhibit which of the following differences in terms of error distributions for stellar parameters?
choices: Lower overall errors for all parameters due to the use of more realistic spatial priors.
Noticeably different error distributions despite similar stellar parameter ranges.
Significantly more catastrophic age errors due to the inclusion of young stars.
Negligible differences in error distributions, demonstrating the robustness of StarHorse to different stellar models.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 7 shows that StarHorse tends to overestimate ages compared to the PARAM code. What is the approximate median age offset?
